摄影模特发布：你需要知道什么（带样本）一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是杰夫·盖耶。

十年前，当我辞去律师职务时，我知道我正在用公文包换取相机包，用法庭换取工作室。然而，我不知道合同会继续占据我的大部分时间。

您和客户之间合同的重要性几乎是理所当然的，但同样重要（甚至更重要）的是模特授权书。如果您从事专业拍摄一段时间，您已经知道（我希望）从您拍摄的人物那里获得模特授权是绝对必要的。

然而，您可能不知道它为何如此重要。不幸的是，大多数人既没有完全阅读也没有理解他们签署或为其准备的法律文件。您的技巧袋中可能有一个铁定的模型发布，但您可能不明白它到底发布了什么或该语言的意义。

从长远来看，对基础知识有更全面的了解将对您有很大帮助，特别是在评估您是否需要模型授权书，并说服您的拍摄对象签署模型授权书（如果需要）时。

什么是模型发布，为什么它很重要？

从最基本的角度来说，模特授权书是一份合同：您和您所拍摄的人之间签署的书面协议。

模特授权书的目的是保护（即免除）您在未来的诉讼中免于承担责任，您的主题/模特可能会因侵犯隐私、诽谤等法律索赔而对您提起诉讼。

该文件规定了一方可以使用另一方拍摄的照片的条款。模特授权书通常很简短（不超过一个段落），但也可能会很长，特别是如果模特想在授权书上添加其他条件（例如，没有 Photoshop）。

我们稍后会详细介绍模型发布的具体内容。不过，现在要知道，对于任何商业用途的照片来说，模特授权书都是至关重要的一张纸。

我如何知道我是否需要模特授权书？

并非所有包含人物的照片都需要模特授权，因此首先了解您要进行的摄影类型是否需要模特授权非常重要。

您应该始终从一个基本前提开始：

您是否需要模特授权并不主要取决于图像的内容。相反，这取决于图像的用途。

当您从这个前提开始时（需求主要由用途而不是内容决定），您会遇到一组非常基本的问题：

问题1：照片会用于商业用途吗？

在确定模特发布的重要性时，您应该问的第一个问题是“这张照片会用于商业用途吗？”如果答案是“是”，您需要模特授权书。如果答案是“否”，则您不需要模特授权书。很简单，对吧？不完全的！ （继续阅读。）

仅仅因为图像被发布，其本身并不自动意味着该使用是商业性的。例如，仅出现在报纸、教育书籍以及消费者或贸易出版物中的作品不需要模型发布，因为它是编辑使用，有时称为“合理使用”。

另一方面，商业用途可以包括广告、宣传册、网络使用、贺卡、目录、时事通讯等。对于商业、许可用途，您绝对必须拥有模型授权书。

什么是商业用途，什么不是商业用途有时会令人困惑。假设您拍摄了当地一位受欢迎的厨师的照片，但尚未获得签名的模特授权书。你的朋友是当地一家报纸的出版商，他付钱给你这张照片，以便在他们发表的有关该餐厅的文章中使用。由于该照片被用作新闻报道的一部分，因此这构成编辑用途。金钱易手的事实并不自动使其成为商业用途的照片，并且缺乏模特授权也不是问题。

但是，如果餐厅的公关机构想要使用同一张照片作为广告活动的一部分，您将需要模特授权书。请记住，是否需要模特授权取决于用途，而不是内容 - 在这里，我们讨论的是同一张照片，但具有两种不同的用途。一种需要释放，另一种则不需要。最终，在您能够回答照片将如何使用的问题之前，无法知道您是否需要模特授权书。

下面的示例说明了在确定是否需要模型授权时预期用途的重要性。抗议图片（左侧）是有关削减公共资助艺术项目的国家预算的新闻报道的一部分。这是编辑用途，因此不需要模型发布。国际象棋比赛照片（右上）是为当地旅游业的商业出版物拍摄的。它的原始用途需要模型授权书，但在 dPS 上的编辑发布不需要模型授权书。底部拍摄的人群出现在一篇有关公共教育的新闻文章中，正如您现在所知，该文章不需要发布模特。

问题2：图像的主体是否可识别？

如果您确定该用途确实用于商业用途，那么您必须回答的下一个问题是照片中的人是否具有独特的可识别性并清楚地表明照片的主题。

如果该人无法唯一识别，则无需模特授权书。但就像上面提到的不断变化的边界一样，什么构成和不构成“唯一可识别”并不总是一成不变的。请记住，除了脸部之外，还有多种方法可以识别或识别照片中的某人。有时，剪影、纹身、制服甚至地点都可以识别一个人，而不必露出他们的脸——在这种情况下，你仍然需要模特授权书。

乍一看，下面的三张照片似乎没有可识别的主题，这可能会让您认为没有必要发布模特授权，无论图像用途是商业用途还是社论用途。

让我们假设所有这三个图像确实被指定用于商业用途。就 Parkview 高中的学生（上图）而言，让我们面对现实吧：尽管有人体彩绘、假发和太阳镜，但家长和朋友可以轻松识别每个学生。

纹身（左下）也相当独特，这使得你在照片中看不到纹身艺术家的脸成为一个有争议的问题。她手臂上的墨水足以让人认出她来。

最后，公园里的艺术家理论上可以被识别，不是因为她从这个角度有什么独特之处，而是因为她的绘画的独特性。

换句话说，所有三个示例图像都需要模型发布，简单明了（假设它们将用于商业用途）。

问题3：照片是如何拍摄的以及在哪里拍摄的？

乍一看，这个问题似乎不会产生什么影响，但实际上确实如此。这就是旅行、偷拍和街头摄影等事物发挥作用的地方。我在公共场所（街道、集市、公园、节日等）拍摄的照片通常不需要模特授权书，尤其是当它们注定只存在于我的作品集或墙上时。

然而，如果我认为有一天我可能想将这张照片用于商业用途（请参阅第一个问题！），我必须获得模特授权。这就是为什么我总是建议摄影师谨慎行事，只要有人可以被认出并清楚地成为照片的主题，就可以获得模特授权书。你永远不知道你的档案中可能潜藏着哪些赚钱的图片，直到有人来寻找它们。首先获得模型发布总是比稍后追溯您的步骤并希望得到最好的结果更容易。

在最后一组示例中，我们将了解在公共场所拍摄的照片可能需要或不需要模特授权书。如前所述，街头摄影——无论可识别的面孔如何——都不需要授权，除非它们是用于商业用途。从法律角度来看，您可以在公共场合拍摄任何人，只要您这样做不违反任何其他法律。这并不意味着它总是一个好主意，但这并不意味着它是非法的。

（注意：这确实因地点而异，虽然在美国的公共场所拍照是合法的，但在世界其他地方可能并非如此 - 因此在陌生的地点进行人物摄影之前，请务必检查当地法律。 ）

然而，当出于商业目的拍摄 18 岁以下儿童时，父母或法定监护人必须签署模特授权书。获得未成年人签名不算数。

什么是商业用途？一个简单的定义

简而言之，商业用途就是旨在增强商业利益的用途。我之前列出了一些常见的商业用途，但这一切都归结为某人使用相关照片的目的是否是为了创收。

当我为作者拍摄书籍封面时，这显然是商业性的。除了出现在书的背面外，该照片还可能出现在该书的广告中。它还可能出现在书店的橱窗中宣传这本书、作者出现在签名会上以及其他促销活动中。所有这些活动显然都是为了赚钱，因此识别商业用途非常简单。

然而，使问题变得复杂的是，您拍摄的照片除了将其发布在您的专业网站上的画廊之一之外没有其他任何原因。显然，您并不是在出售实际图像，因此没有钱易手。然而，您正在使用该人的肖像作为您所做工作类型的示例，以期带来更多业务。您对使用该照片的兴趣显然是出于商业目的。

在这种情况下，图像本身并没有实际的金钱收益，因此界限很模糊，但您确实有在网站上展示它的商业目标。同样的道理也适用于在工作室悬挂客户照片。如果展示您的作品样本会鼓励其他潜在客户雇用您，就会带来商业利益。宁可谨慎行事，让你的当事人签署一份模型授权书，也比花时间应对诉讼和停止函要好得多。

模特发布应该说些什么？

这是一些免责声明的地方：

模特发布是一份合同。大多数适用的原则都被广泛接受，但不同州和国家的法律确实有所不同。有许多用于创建模型版本的优秀资源，因此我强烈警告不要简单地编写自己的文档。如果没有必要，为什么要重新发明轮子呢？如果您对此有疑问或不确定，请明智地咨询律师。

合同法最基本的原则是必须“达成共识”。换句话说，有效的合同是一条双向路，以某种方式对各方承担义务。与这一要求齐头并进的是“考虑”。在法律背景下，“考虑”仅意味着有价值的东西。作为摄影师，您要求您拍摄的人放弃对如何、在何处以及何时使用这些照片的任何权利或声称他们可能拥有的权利。这可能是一件大事，你应该准备好为他们提供一些有价值的回报。它可以是象征性的一笔钱，可以是印刷品，也可以是你们两人都同意的其他东西。合同价格低至一美元。模型发布必须承认这一考虑。

同样重要的是要记住，摄影师几乎不是照片的实际发布者。因此，模特授权书必须表明拍摄对象不仅同意您使用这些照片，而且还同意您授权使用这些照片的任何人。

让我们回到厨师的示例照片。假设厨师的代理人或公关人员雇用您为厨师拍摄他们即将出版的食谱的封面。显然，您不是发布者。但是，您将获得该照片的许可，以供发布者使用。您可以这样做的唯一方法是确保模型版本授权您向第三方授予使用权。

如前所述，模型发布可以而且应该简短、精彩、切题。我在相机包里放了一叠印在 3 英寸 x 5 英寸卡片纸上的模型发布。它足够短，足以有效和有效，并且不会使主体感到困惑以致他们拒绝签署。我依靠这个简短的版本来进行更即兴的摄影，而我使用这个较长的版本来进行委托工作。

关于文书工作的另一项注意事项：永远保留。模特发布不是在一段时间后可以扔掉的记录。如果您想获得该图像的许可，您将需要该版本。更重要的是，如果您被起诉，您需要释放自己来为自己辩护。

模型发布很重要！

有些人可能会犹豫，甚至不愿意签署模特授权书。你必须准备好尊重这个决定。当你被雇来拍摄他们的照片时，让一个人签署授权书当然比你在街上闲逛，只拍摄你感兴趣的东西更容易。

我总是确保我的客户在我们开始拍摄之前签署授权书——假设首先需要授权书！请记住，看似复杂的过程可以轻松分解为相当快速的分析。问问自己这张照片是否会以任何方式用于商业用途。如果答案是“否”，询问就停止，您可以随意将照片挂在客厅墙上，想多大就多大。不过，如果您认为有一天您可能想要将照片许可用于商业用途，那么获得签名的模特授权书是绝对必要的。

这是我的较长模型发布，用于委托工作。

如何拍摄葬礼（有品味和尊重）的帖子首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是Hannele Luhtasela-el Showk 。

对于我们大多数人来说，摄影是一项有趣而快乐的活动，我们可以做自己喜欢的事情并与他人分享。事实上，世界各地的专业摄影师一直都被要求将人们一生中最幸福的时光永垂不朽：家庭和生活的开始、重要的仪式、庆祝的成就。拍摄葬礼在很多层面上都是非常不同的。

尽管葬礼似乎不是人们想要记住的那种活动，但事实往往如此。毕竟，这是一个重要的仪式，是对生命的庆祝，也是对彼此可能不太了解但团结一致哀悼的人们的聚会。

根据我的经验，许多人发现记录亲人的葬礼很重要，即使这是一项摄影服务，没有像其他服务那样广泛宣传或讨论或以相同的方式（例如，高级肖像、家庭照片等） 。

拍摄葬礼：您需要了解的信息

注意：本文中的所有图像均已获得家庭批准在此处使用。未经书面许可，不得将任何图像用于此敏感主题。

在某种程度上，准备拍摄葬礼与任何其他摄影工作几乎没有什么不同。但显然有一些独特的考虑因素，在本文中，我将讨论相似之处和重要差异。

我想强调一件事：

不要将拍摄葬礼作为您的第一份摄影工作，甚至不要将其作为您的第二份工作。葬礼摄影需要专业、冷静的态度、丰富的经验和高质量的作品。正确完成这一点很重要——因此，如果您被要求记录一场葬礼，而您之前从未真正拍摄过任何严肃的活动摄影，您应该温和地鼓励客户询问那些拍摄过更多照片的人。 （至少，强调你以前从未做过这样的事情；你想确保他们知道他们得到了什么。）

葬礼前

葬礼是生命周期中的一个基本事件，对于想要雇用你的人来说，它无疑会带来很多情绪。

葬礼摄影不像其他类型的摄影那样受到广泛讨论——没有关于葬礼摄影的杂志或展览会，社交媒体上也很少分享葬礼照片。因此，与客户的良好沟通比平时更加​​重要。请记住，与您打交道的人可能无法准确表达他们正在寻找的东西，他们自然会感到压力和不安。

因此，请确保提出很多问题，并在客户似乎遇到困难时尝试提供意见和建议。当然，您应该以最大的敏感度来完成这一切；目标不是炫耀您的专业精神或专业知识，而是了解期望什么以及客户想要什么。

如果可能的话，在哀悼者进入之前拍一些照片。这样，您就可以捕捉更广阔的场景。不过，在进入之前一定要询问。

以下是葬礼前需要了解的最重要的事情：

  • 仪式将于何时何地举行？如果可能的话，请提前参观该地点，熟悉场地。 （当您在那里时，请考虑一下光线情况。考虑一下光线会如何根据天气和一天中的时间而变化，特别是如果场地有大窗户的话。）
  • 会是什么样的仪式呢？如果您要拍摄一个您不熟悉的仪式，请确保您了解有关它的所有信息。这是出于几个关键原因：这样您就可以更好地了解当天会发生什么，这样您就可以知道仪式的哪些元素最重要（因此应该最仔细地记录下来），这样您就可以避免拍照时做出任何不当或不尊重的行为。此外，如果您觉得自己无法在葬礼日期前自信地拍摄某个仪式，请立即与您的客户沟通，以便他们可以找到其他人。正如我上面强调的，葬礼摄影必须做好，如果你不确定自己是否能胜任这项任务，现在还不是耸耸肩说“好吧，我会尽力而为！”的时候。
  • 哪些具体照片对客户来说特别重要？例如，有些人可能希望您专注于布道和悼词，而另一些人可能会要求您优先考虑哀悼者的照片或宗教细节。
  • 顾客与死者是什么关系？

在葬礼当天，穿深色衣服（并根据您的问题和研究确保它适合仪式）。另外，请穿可以让您四处走动而不会造成干扰的鞋子。

当然，一定要准时到达会场，问候你的客户，并表达你的哀悼。

拍摄仪式

拍摄葬礼时最大的挑战是在拍摄漂亮照片和不干扰仪式之间找到适当的平衡。确保保持安静并避免挡住哀悼者的视线，但请记住，您是付费来拍摄这一事件的。您的客户要求您帮助家人和朋友记住重要的一天和亲人的生活，因此您必须做好自己的工作，而且必须做好。

寻找空间中那些可以让你创作有意义的图像同时又不妨碍人们的区域——这是提前参观场地的另一种方式，可以提供很大的帮助——无论你做什么，都不要使用闪光灯。另外，如果你的相机有静音或电子拍摄模式，那就使用它；大多数现代无反光镜相机都提供此选项，它通常会让您的快门难以察觉。将噪音调整（例如镜头更换）保持在绝对最低限度 - 如果您想在焦距之间切换、携带两个相机或使用高质量变焦。

您绝对必须拍摄的照片取决于相关仪式的类型，也取决于客户的愿望。但是，您应该努力拍摄以下几种常见类型的图像：

  • 哀悼者表达哀悼
  • 宗教（如果是宗教）仪式的基本部分
  • 葬礼和最后的告别

您被要求拍摄一个非常私密的活动，因此请记住，拍摄客人时应该谨慎且尊重。对于许多人来说，客人的照片是您要拍摄的最重要的照片：它们代表着死者丰富生活的不同部分，代表着死者将继续生活在他们的记忆中的人们。有些人可能想要一张所有客人的合影（如果您不确定是否感兴趣，请提前询问）。

仪式的细节和特定部分对于拍摄也很重要：插花、棺材的下降以及仪式的牧师或领导者。

葬礼结束后

当仪式（或你被要求拍摄的部分）结束时，让你的客户知道你要离开，再次表达你的哀悼，并称赞他们的活动是多么美好。

之后立即回家并备份您的照片。然后给自己喘口气，照顾好自己。参与此类活动对您的影响可能比您意识到的要大。

图像选择过程和编辑应该像往常一样进行。您应该专业并及时提供图像。请记住要非常尊重并尽可能创作出最有品味的照片。如果您不确定图像是否有品味/合适，最好将其从交付给客户的图像中排除。

尊重、专业、包容客户

葬礼是悲伤、纪念和团聚的活动。捕捉所有这些，而不仅仅是黑暗，很重要。

然而，最重要的是在整个过程中保持同理心。您越关注客户的需求，就越能有效地创造出客户所寻求的图像，而且对每个人来说都越好。

没有什么比把你的照片展示在墙上让每个人都能看到、欣赏和欣赏更好的了。更好的是看到印刷品下面的那些小圆形红色贴纸，表明该作品已售出。

对于大多数艺术家来说，展出作品是一种驱动力——对于为墙壁和画廊展示拍摄图像的摄影师来说尤其如此。

但举办一个摄影展可能比你想象的要困难。您必须考虑一系列问题，例如：

  • 你应该在哪里展示你的作品？
  • 你如何提交照片？
  • 你如何给你的工作定价？
  • 你买保险吗？
  • 你应该如何构图你的照片（如果有的话）？

展示您的作品也可能非常昂贵，因此在采取行动之前了解基本成本非常重要。

在本文中，我的目标是回答所有这些问题（以及更多！）。这样，如果您决定继续举办展览，您就会知道如何使其尽可能成功。

为什么要办摄影展？

几个世纪以来，艺术家们一直在展示他们的作品，今天也不例外——尽管展示照片的一些原因已经发生了变化。

在互联网出现之前，展览是展示作品的最佳方式之一，艺术家利用展览来赚钱。他们会邀请特殊的客户或捐助者参加开幕式，希望他们能购买一件或几件。

如今出售艺术品变得更加困难，因此如果您参展的唯一原因是出售您的照片，那么您可能会非常失望。然而，如果您的目标是将您的作品挂在墙上，向人们展示您作为艺术家的能力，那么展览可能会非常有价值。听我说：让大家看到你最好的作品感觉是一项相当大的成就。

许多艺术家举办展览的另一个原因是将展览写进艺术家的简历中。简历（或简历）是您所有展览的列表，以及您的教育背景和其他一些内容，类似于简历。这是画廊在考虑是否展示您的作品时所考虑的因素。

成本和预算

展览并不便宜！因此，在您决定全力以赴参加展览之前，您需要考虑许多因素，包括：

  • 您将在什么样的空间展出？入场费用是多少？
  • 还会有什么其他费用？
  • 您将为展览准备多少图像？复制费用是多少？
  • 您应该举办个展还是从群展开始？

这些都是您需要考虑的问题，我将在下面更详细地讨论。

团体展览与个人展览

个展非常棒，它们最终是每个艺术家想要的。 （想象一下，有一个完整的展览专门展示您的图像！）但是个展也非常昂贵，特别是因为您没有任何人可以与您分担费用。

因此，大多数艺术家不是一头扎进个展，而是从群展开始。然后，如果他们取得了一些成功，他们就会进入个人表演。

团体表演是一个入门并开始建立艺术家简历的好方法。开始集体展览的方法有很多种，但我鼓励你找到一些也对展览感兴趣的朋友，然后一起向画廊申请，看看是否可以获得展览。

许多画廊也会举办自己的群展，他们经常会刊登广告邀请艺术家参加——所以你可以经常留意并申请！

在哪里展示您的照片

老实说，您可能可以创建一个无尽的展览可能性清单，但是最常见的地方是专门从事您创建的作品类型的画廊。

但是，还有其他地方，例如咖啡馆或餐馆，喜欢在墙上举办不同艺术品的展览。每种方法都有好处和缺点：

在咖啡馆，餐馆和门厅展出

这些地方通常可以让您免费展示，而且它们并不总是有时间表，因此有时您可以在画廊中进行工作时间比您的工作更长的时间。

咖啡馆和餐馆可能不希望从销售工作中进行佣金，但他们可能希望您处理所有销售，因此您需要留下联系信息。而且他们通常不会对您的艺术作品承担任何责任，因此请注意（换句话说，损失和损害不会涵盖）。

在其中一个地方展出时，您将无法访问邮件列表，您必须自己做所有广告。人们通常不仅徘徊去看工作。当然，客户会看到您的图像，但出于特定原因（例如，吃午餐），他们在那里，购买图像不是其中之一。虽然您可以从咖啡馆展览中出售作品，但您的听众并不是在那里购买您的出售产品，这使得这种类型的展览更加被动。

您的工作很可能需要被绞死，并且您可能必须在展览空间内安装它。

在画廊展出

画廊有许多不同类型的画廊，由您决定哪种类型最适合您的摄影作品。这是要记住的基本画廊类别：

艺术家经营的空间

最便宜的使用空间通常是艺术家经营的。您付出的付出少于展示自己的作品，但希望您“参加展览”。这意味着您必须在画廊开放以观察您的工作并管理任何销售时就在那里。

参加画廊开放的整个时间都可能很耗时。许多艺术家将聚在一起参加小组展览，分配租用空间的成本，并绘制一个名册来参加展览。对于刚开始的艺术家来说，这可能是一个更好的选择。如果您想进行分截面的小组表演，但不认识任何人可以展示，请尝试与画廊联系；他们可能知道一些想分享演出的艺术家。

虽然艺术家经营的空间并没有获得高额的预付费用，但您需要支付大多数剩余费用。开口的成本由您覆盖和组织。您还必须支付大多数广告费用，尽管某些画廊将有一个邮件列表供您使用。

配备人员的画廊

配备人员是下一个层次。他们的成本更高，但是您可以减轻必须参加展览的负担。

员工有两种类型的员工画廊 - 商业和非商业 - 他们经常以不同的方式工作。

非商业画廊

这些通常是较小的画廊，可以为您租用空间并为您坐在摄影展览会上。它们通常是展览最昂贵的画廊。非商业画廊将有助于宣传开幕式，但他们通常对在展览之外促进您和您的工作不感兴趣；换句话说，这种关系是短期的。

非商业画廊从您的租金中赚钱。他们还从您出售的任何工作（通常约为30％）中获取佣金。这些画廊是开始在简历上工作的好方法。有些人还做很多小组表演，所以我建议您看看您是否可以参加工作。

只要工作质量良好，非商业画廊通常不会对展览品的展示挑剔。他们不介意一个展览是否都是抽象的绘画，而下一个是所有景观照片。在其中一个画廊中，与商业画廊相比，在其中一个画廊中演出可能要容易得多。

商业画廊

商业画廊很难参加展览。他们有许多艺术家可供选择，通常考虑到特定类型的艺术家。他们对短期关系不太感兴趣，并且对帮助您确立自己的艺术家之一的兴趣更感兴趣 - 换句话说，他们想代表您。

商业画廊将使您的某些工作在仓库中，并宣传您的工作。他们试图让收藏家查看您的工作（因此收藏家也将开始收集和支持您）。

商业画廊通常代表利基市场。如果您将照片发送到仅处理土著艺术的画廊，那么它们就不会感兴趣。因此，在接近这些画廊时，您需要进行研究。确保您的作品适合他们代表的其他艺术家。同时，如果他们有另一个与您的工作几乎相同的艺术家，那么他们也不会感兴趣。诀窍是找到合适的照片的画廊，但也有些独特。

商业画廊的成本通常要少得多。但是，他们很难参加演出，并将接受更高的佣金。 （在澳大利亚，这种速度通常约为40％，而非商业画廊获得的30％。）

将您的工作提交画廊

当现在是提交建议的好时机时，大多数画廊都会做广告。虽然您可以在其他时间发送查询，但最好检查他们的网站以了解提交日期（即，他们要求人们发送展览建议的时间）。

委员会和定价您的工作

所有画廊都收取佣金，有些咖啡馆也这样做。定价工作时，您需要考虑此金额。请确保在第一次查询在该领域的展览时发现佣金百分比。

另外，在定价方面，您应该是现实的。如果您是艺术界的新手，那么为您的工作收取数千美元是不可行的。只有成熟的艺术家才能这样的价格。要了解您可以实际收取的内容，请查看您要展示的空间，看看以前的艺术家为类似作品收取了多少收费。如果您对价格感到满意，则可以尝试对价格充电。

随着您声誉的增长，越来越多的人开始购买您的作品，您可以考虑收取更多费用。

处理损坏或盗窃造成的损失

当您租用空间来展示您的工作时，您也承担了其责任。即使是画廊也不太可能涵盖对您的艺术品的任何盗窃或损害。

这通常是在合同或条款中。确保您知道，如果您担心，那么保险可能是一种选择。

确保您的工作

正如我所说，如果损坏或被盗，大多数地方都不会覆盖您的工作。因此，保险是展示艺术品时需要考虑的东西。您需要购买保险吗？实际上，大多数艺术家不必担心，但这并不意味着您应该做同样的事情。我建议做一些研究；看看它将花费多少，如果感觉值得。

现在，如果工作要花很多钱，那么保险就更为重要。您还可以与画廊交谈，看看他们过去是否有问题，尤其是盗窃。

另外，如果这项工作进入了一个高流量区，例如人行道，可能会损坏它，或者有人可以随身携带它，那么绝对值得考虑。

归根结底，您是否获得保险单应取决于工作本身，还应取决于展览空间。如果您的工作在咖啡馆中显示，那么工作人员可能根本没有时间观看工作，尤其是在忙碌的期间。画廊将有一个更好的观看位置 - 但前提是他们有工作人员。如果您必须自己坐在空间，可以观看一切吗？

你应该构架你的工作吗？

许多地方会为您回答框架的问题：他们要么说必须构架工作，要么可以将其固定在墙上。

如果必须构架工作，则必须决定是否负担得起。获得自定义框架可能非常昂贵。因此，许多艺术家将所有作品的尺寸都相同（或使用相同的尺寸框架，然后根据图像更改垫子的尺寸）。然后，他们去像宜家这样的地方购买便宜的框架。如果您自己进行框架，那么每次要进行表演时都可以重复使用帧。

如果您不必构架印刷品并可以将图像固定在墙上，那并不意味着您无法完成作品。同样，您需要考虑预算。但是，如果您选择将图像固定在墙上，则需要找出做到这一点的最佳方法。如果演出的目的是出售您的作品，那么您的照片中的针孔对于潜在的买家来说可能是不可取的。另外，Unframed Prints看起来不像专业人士或完成（买家不能仅仅将无框印刷品带回家并将其挂在墙上）。

您应该展示几张图像，以及什么尺寸？

确定要准备多少工作以及打印多大的价格归结为价格和空间。您的展览预算只能由您确定 - 您可以制作多少件，以及您的工作大小，将由您的预算确定。

知道您有多少可供展览的空间。如果该空间只有3 m（10 ft）的墙壁空间，那么将三个图像放置为一米（39英寸）的图像将使它变得拥挤，并且每张照片之间不允许足够的空间。但是，如果您有10 m（33 ft）的空间，并且张起了四个仅50厘米（20英寸）的图像，则可以为您之间的空间太多。

仔细考虑空间。如果您认为扩大时的作品看起来很棒，那么也许较少的大块会更好。但是它们越大，花费就越多。

图像数量也是如此。您不想完全填充空间 - 给每个图像室将使它们得到更好的显示。仅仅因为您为空间付款并不意味着您必须填写它。而且，如果您选择框架，请考虑框架的大小！

编写您的摄影

版本也称为“限量版”，是摄影需要考虑的东西。版画家已经这样做了几个世纪。这意味着您向潜在客户保证，只有一定数量的图像（打印）才能出售。

版本可能是使您的作品更有价值的好方法。如果您有图像并制作20版，则需要确保买家知道他们收到的版本中的数字（例如，8/20）。您需要保留此记录，以便知道您出售的图像的打印量。一旦卖出20，您就不会再出售了。您向购买前20个购买的人做出了承诺，您只会出售其中的20个。想一想您从一开始就可以出售的照片有多少印刷品，并保持现实。

您需要谨慎使用的另一件事是确保将照片打印到完全相同的情况下。他们都必须保持一致。如果您在演出中放一件作品并出售几次，如果他们收到的图像与他们在展览中看到的图像不同，人们就不会感到高兴。您不必同时让它们全部打印，但是请确保您对所有打印机都使用相同的打印机，并且打印机知道如何将它们相同复制。

选择印刷媒介

您选择的打印媒介应由预算确定 - 但您还应该考虑如何使您的工作看起来最好。您想要框架打印吗？还是您要打印的图像类型更好？在金属上打印的工作现在也变得流行，尽管它也很昂贵，并且（可以说）仅适合某些摄影风格。

无论您选择什么，都需要小心。您想以最好的方式炫耀自己的作品。考虑以几种不同的方式打印一些图像，然后确定最喜欢哪个图像。

选择要展示的图像

对于大多数人来说，选择要包括在展览中的图像是最难的部分。您怎么知道哪些图像最能显示？没有真正的方法可以说。

如果您正在与雇用策展人的画廊合作，则可能会从中获得很多帮助；他们可以利用画廊的经验以及卖给您建议的东西。如果没有策展人，您可能必须寻求朋友的帮助。要求他们确定自己喜欢的作品。也许您的社交媒体网站还可以帮助您看到在线最受欢迎的图像。

在策划展览时，应该对作品和最后展览具有凝聚力。确保所有工作都合在一起并流动良好。明确您对展览的愿景。您的图像在墙壁上的外观越好，您可以出售的越多。

作为摄影师，选择最佳的云存储并不像选择最便宜的选项那样简单，但也不是太复杂了。有很多不错的选择，归根结底，最重要的是找到适合您并满足您需求的存储包。

一些摄影师需要储存的储存量，这些存储在任何地方都可以立即访问，而另一些摄影师的需求也更为适中。但是，其他选择中的一些选择（我认为您也最好避免使用一些选择）。

直到最近，摄影的云存储更多是一种奢侈品，而不是必需的。数字图像仅使用昂贵的数码单反相机或专用的口袋摄像头拍摄，该摄像头存储在台式计算机上，备份到外部硬盘驱动器，并通过电子邮件或发布在社交媒体上发布或发布与他人共享。云存储很昂贵，缓慢且负担重大，可以设置和管理 - 通常是为IT专业人士而不是摄影师设计的。

但是，俗话说，现代摄影需要现代解决方案。现在，即使是最随意的摄影师，云存储也可以触及，它也可以满足苛刻的专业人士的需求。实际上，摄影师可以使用许多云存储选项，并且能够适合各种工作流程和存储要求。

价格，速度和存储容量仍然值得考虑，但它们不是以前进入的进入障碍。现在，决定云存储是否适合您（可能是！）并不是问题。相反，问题是哪种云存储最适合您，值得庆幸的是，有很多很棒的选择。

iPhone摄影师的最佳云存储：iCloud

虽然这似乎有点像警察或一个过于简单的答案，但我确实认为iPhone摄影师的最佳云存储是Apple的iCloud服务。 iCloud会自动备份iPhone上的所有照片，并在所有其他Apple设备（包括iPad，iMac和MacBooks）中提供它们。

您的编辑也跨设备同步，因此，如果您在iPhone上裁剪照片，它也会在其他任何地方裁剪。可以与他人共享存储在iCloud中的照片，您可以选择在iCloud中存储原件，同时在iPhone上保留小缩略图。这是一种释放手机上空间的好方法，并且还可以降低您的成本，因为您不需要在手机上花费数百美元的内部存储空间。

所有iPhone用户免费获得5 GB的iCloud存储空间。这几乎不足以存储不仅仅是少数照片和视频，而且如果您还需要备份基本的iPhone数据和文档，几乎可以肯定不会满足您的需求。

幸运的是，iCloud存储的价格相当合理：最低层的选项每月的价格仅为99美分，可为您提供50 GB的云存储，而下一个层（以及我建议大多数人的推荐）提供200 GB的存储空间每月$ 2.99。

iCloud Pros：

  • 合理的价格使其比其他云存储选项更实惠
  • 几乎不需要设置和使用
  • 与其他Apple设备无缝集成

iCloud Cons：

  • 对于Android用户来说，这不是一个不错的选择
  • 共享选项可能令人沮丧
  • 如果您需要超过200 GB的存储空间，成本会大大增加

适用于Android摄影师的最佳云存储：Google One

与我上面的iCloud建议一样，Android摄影师的最佳云存储是Google One。它廉价，易于使用，并与Google Photos无缝集成，这是世界上使用最广泛的摄影平台之一。

任何拥有Google帐户的人免费获得15 GB的存储空间，尽管这比iCloud提供的更多免费存储空间，但是一旦您开始使用高分辨率的照片和视频填充它，它就非常有限。免费的15 GB版本将用户从Google的某些照片编辑工具中锁定，例如Magic Eraser和Protait Blur将用户锁定出来，这也有些令人沮丧。

幸运的是，100 GB的额外存储空间仅为$ 2/月。 （一旦精疲力尽，下一个可用的选项明显昂贵，为2汤匙10美元/月。）

Google一个人很容易为Android用户推荐，因为就像它的iCloud同行一样，它非常易于使用。它的大部分操作（例如将照片备份到云中）会自动发生，而无需用户干预。另外，Google Photos在组织图像，标记人员，查找对象并让您根据需要分享图片和视频方面做得很好。

Google一个专业人士：

  • 拥有Google帐户的任何人免费存储15 GB
  • 与Google照片集成以进行简单备份和云存储
  • 简单的照片组织和共享

Google一个缺点：

  • 廉价的100 GB和非常昂贵的2 TB之间没有中层存储升级选项
  • 免费版本缺少许多照片编辑工具

DSLR和无反光镜摄影师的最佳云存储：Dropbox

与基于移动的同行相比，依靠数码单反相比的摄影师通常有不同的需求。换句话说，如果您用更传统的相机拍摄，并且需要存储，组织和备份数千个（或数十万）高分辨率的图像和原始文件，那么您将需要与iCloud或Google不同的东西一。 Dropbox是最佳选择 - 不仅是为了价格和存储选择，还针对某些功能，这些功能非常适合满足DSLR和无反光镜摄影师的需求。

Dropbox很容易推荐，因为它做得非常好：它可以在所有设备上提供快速，可靠，高度可定制的云存储和同步，这非常适合DSLR和无反光镜射击游戏。 Dropbox也已经存在了十多年，并且作为云存储市场的主要参与者之一，不会很快去任何地方。您知道您的图像将在未来几年内安全存储。

每月10美元的计划为您提供了2 TB的存储空间，类似于Icloud和Google One，但是Dropbox在笔记本电脑，台式机以及Android和iOS设备上的功能非常好。它在高速（包括原始文件）上同步图像的负载毫不费力，并允许您根据需要组织照片。

Dropbox ProS：

  • 快速，可靠且易于用于存储图像以及其他文件和文档
  • 跨多个设备同步
  • 包括用于iPhone和Android的功能强大的移动应用程序
  • 多个家庭成员可以共享一个Dropbox计划

Dropbox Cons：

  • 用于存储照片的效果很好，但不是专门为摄影师设计的
  • 可用于与客户共享图像，但不提供可自定义的画廊

专业摄影师的最佳云存储：自鸣得意

如果您依靠相机装备来支付账单，并且您需要存储和管理需要大量的客户端图像，那么您需要为可以跟上工作流程的云存储选项付费。 Smugmug是专业人士的最佳选择，因为它不仅提供了良好的云存储；它还拥有销售图像的客户画廊和电子商务选项。这并不便宜，但是如果您的生计取决于您的相机和产生的文件，这是值得的。

Smugmug不是为业余爱好者和业余爱好者设计的，也没有免费计划。所有自鸣得意的软件包均以每年$ 120的价格起价，均用于专业摄影师，并包括无限的照片存储以及创建有效展示您图像的画廊和网站的工具。 $ 246/年的计划有用于销售图像，给您的照片加水印并向客户交付文件的工具。

尽管休闲射击者当然可以使用自鸣得意的服务，但他们会更好地选择此列表中的其他选项之一。但是对于专业人士来说，Smugmug拥有完整的云存储，客户 - 美容和电子商务解决方案所需的一切，并且很容易推荐。

Smugmug Pros：

  • 专业摄影师的全面工具和服务套件
  • 无限的照片存储，包括对原始文件的支持
  • 易于上传图像以及管理，排序和组织照片和原始文件

自鸣得意的缺点：

  • 比其他云存储选项更昂贵
  • 不是为休闲或业余摄影师设计的

业余爱好者和业余摄影师的最佳云存储：Adobe Lightroom计划

现在，如果您喜欢摄影并想要高级编辑工具来增强您的创造力，但是您并没有以拍照为生，那么我鼓励您订阅Adobe的Lightroom（1 TB）计划。

每月10美元的选项提供1 TB的云存储，同时还包括访问Lightroom，这是数字资产管理和编辑的黄金标准。对于想要超越Apple照片或Google照片的人们来说，这是一个完美的解决方案，并且很容易推荐，因为它包含足够的存储空间，可容纳数以万计的图像以及高级共享选项。它甚至包括一套完整的教育工具。

Lightroom会自动将图像上传到云中 - 无论您使用手机，数码单反相机，无反光镜模型还是任何其他相机。它可以在所有设备上同步您的图像，并且可以创建可以与朋友，家人和其他任何人在线共享的精美自定义画廊。移动Lightroom应用程序非常易于使用，并提供高级编辑功能（例如掩盖和颜色分级） ，而且可以在平板电脑，台式机上访问，甚至可以在网络浏览器上访问。

最后，该计划通过易于使用的Adobe Portfolio平台为用户提供了五个自定义网站，这是为您的图像创建可公开可查看的展示柜的绝佳方法。虽然1 TB计划的存储量不如其他服务的存储空间那么多，但对于大多数业余爱好者和业余摄影师来说，它足够了，它包括您需要编辑，组织和分享照片的所有软件， 也。

Adobe Lightroom专业人士：

  • 唯一的云存储选项，其中包括一套完整的编辑，发布和共享工具
  • 提供访问Lightroom Discover平台，该平台使您可以向其他摄影师学习并获得大量培训材料
  • Lightroom会收到定期更新，这些更新增加了有意义的改进和功能

Adobe Lightroom Cons：

  • 价格类似于其他云存储选项，但没有太多空间
  • 用RAW拍摄的摄影师将迅速达到其存储限制
  • 额外的存储很昂贵（每TByte $ 10）
  • Lightroom不如Lightroom Classic有用，这不是1 TB云存储计划的一部分

摄影师的最佳云存储备份：Backblaze

许多摄影师不需要此列表中其他软件随附的编辑工具，共享选项和其他功能。相反，它们需要岩石固定解决方案，以简单的图像备份和恢复。这种类型的云存储通常在背景中运行，在备份计算机上的所有内容（或仅某些文件夹，具体取决于您喜欢的内容）时悄悄地嗡嗡作响。

当灾难袭击并且您丢失了数十万张照片时，您需要一个备用选项来快速恢复它们。有很多不错的选择 - 例如Idrive，Crashplan和Carbonite-但我推荐的摄影师是Backblaze 。

虽然这不是云存储备份的最便宜的选择，但Backblaze并不是最昂贵的。我认为它在价格和功能之间达到了很好的平衡，尤其是与同行相比。 Backblaze的99美元/年计划将在整体存储方面备份您的所有图像，这对于摄影师来说是理想的，尤其是那些以RAW拍摄的摄影师。

信任和可靠性也是这里的因素；任何人都可以做出巨大的承诺，但证据在布丁中。 Backblaze从事业务已有15年以上，并在此期间以信任，安全性和可靠性赢得了声誉。这不是一个闪烁的，这里是today-gone-tomort的操作，您可以信任公司在需要时拥有您的照片。

Backblaze Pros：

  • 即使对于休闲摄影师，也很实惠
  • 没有限制存储；您可以根据需要备份任意数量的照片
  • 如果需要，很容易恢复所有数据；您甚至可以选择在外部硬盘驱动器上运往您

Backblaze Cons：

  • 比某些同龄人贵一些，这些同龄人会随着时间的推移加起来
  • 仅用于备份；不包括图像编辑和共享工具

摄影师的其他良好云存储选项

不确定我的建议是否适合您的需求？没关系！以下是要考虑的更多存储选项：

亚马逊照片：如果您已经为Amazon Prime付费并且需要一个云存储选项，但尚未准备就绪，这是一个不错的选择。它会自动备份所有图像，包括原始文件，并允许您从网络或移动应用程序访问它们。尽管亚马逊照片效果很好，但它的功能不像此列表中的其他选项那样完整，而且我发现它有时会很慢，越来越大。尽管如此，值得考虑的是一个简单的异地备份选项，尤其是如果您已经为Amazon Prime付费。

个人云服务：像Synology这样的公司一直对您自己的个人云服务进行大规模侵害，通常是位于电缆调制解调器或路由器附近的小型盒子的形式。这些NAS（网络连接的存储）选项如果您的房屋燃烧，则不会保存您的照片，但是它们确实可以让您从任何地方访问您的图像，并且通常包括移动应用程序和共享功能。个人云服务不需要订阅，因为您要管理设备及其存储空间，而且如果您用完了空间，则只需添加另一个硬盘驱动器或SSD即可。 The learning curve is a little steep, so I don't recommend them for beginners, but these tools are a good option for photographers who don't mind a high upfront cost and are willing to do a bit of work to manage things on their自己的。

One-time-purchase services: There are plenty of subscription-based cloud storage options for photographers, but there are also services that promise essentially the same thing but for a one-time fee. This can sound appealing, but I never recommend such a route. It costs money to maintain servers, develop software, fix software vulnerabilities, and adapt to rapidly changing technologies. Subscription fees offer a way for companies to do all of this, so I would not recommend trusting your photos or other data to any company that claims to do the same for a one-time price.

最后的话

The best cloud storage for photographers is a bit subjective, but the options on this list will work great if you fall into one of the categories described above.

And if you still aren't exactly sure what cloud storage will meet your exact needs, just remember that any cloud storage is better than none at all. Try one of the options here, or ask around to see what other photographers prefer. Most cloud storage platforms have trial periods, and even if you sign up for one and don't like it, you can always cancel and switch to another one.

Finally, if you have a storage service you like, share it in the comments below!

I'm talking about tilt-shift photography, a genre that seems to have gained in popularity over the last handful of years. It's all about taking a photograph of a real-world scene and making it look like a miniature scene. Highly detailed miniatures have always fascinated me, so tilt-shift photography was a natural draw. The White House? Shrink it.皮卡迪利马戏团？ Make it Lilliput Lane!

不去爱的种种？

Below, I've shared all the basics of tilt-shift photography. That way, you can learn how to create a miniature effect just like mine – either in-camera or with post-processing.

让我们开始吧！

What is tilt-shift photography?

Tilt-shift photography involves applying a miniaturization effect to the image, which makes the scene look like a toy model:

As you can see in the example above, the tilt-shift effect relies on both foreground and background blurring to create the illusion of a small world.

Now, tilt-shift photography can be done in two broad ways:

  1. Optically, using a tilt-shift lens . Tilt-shift lenses do a great job of creating the effect that we're after. The problem is that they're very expensive, and there aren't very many options to choose from. That's why most photographers prefer to create the effect using the second technique:
  2. In post-processing, generally using Photoshop. The procedure in Photoshop is not complicated, and once you become relatively familiar with the steps, it can be accomplished in as little as one minute.

I recommend the post-processing route, but it's worth mentioning that you don't even need to own Photoshop (or any editing program) to make a tilt-shift photo. Tiltshiftmaker.com has a free service that lets you create the effect with an uploaded photo. And if you want a bit more control, you can always use Fotor's online tilt-shift feature .

How to choose a photo for the tilt-shift treatment

Like anything in photography, the tilt-shift effect can be done, but can it be done well?这就是问题所在。 You can't use any random photo – instead, you must choose the right kind of image. And once a candidate photo is picked, the tilt-shift post-processing procedure must also be done correctly.

So what constitutes a good photo for a tilt-shift treatment? Here's what I've discovered:

  • The photo should be taken from above, but not directly overhead. This reflects what someone taking a photo of a miniature scene would likely do; it's unlikely they would (or even could) be directly above the subject. And if you do have a direct overhead shot, you generally won't end up with a deep depth of field, which is very important. You can capture this type of image using a drone, but an easier approach is to shoot city scenes from the window of a building or the top of a parking garage.
  • A simple scene is usually better than a complicated scene. This is because miniature scenes are usually simple, and we're trying to mimic a toy model. You wouldn't find a dense city block, for example, in a model railroad scene.
  • The photo must be tack-sharp and well-lit. There will be enough blur in the photo from the tilt-shift effect. Your focal point must be sharp; otherwise, the impact will be lost. You also want to ensure you have plenty of depth of field in your initial file, and that the shot is well-exposed, without deep shadows. (The goal is to keep things relatively bright!)
  • If people are in the scene, they need to be relatively small and light on detail. Once again, this is to reflect what you'd see in a real miniature scene. People are small and not well-detailed in miniature scenery!
  • Make sure the scene is interesting . You can create a convincing tilt-shift effect with a variety of aerial photos, but for the most impact, you should go for an image with interest . An aerial photo of a cathedral with spires and flying buttresses is interesting, while an aerial photo of a flat-topped shopping mall is a lot less eye-catching.

Now, if you don't have any aerial images in your portfolio, or you simply don't enjoy shooting aerials , can you still do tilt-shift photography?是的，一点没错！ But I recommend getting as high off the ground as possible, even if it just means shooting at eye level. And for the most convincing effects, you'll definitely need to experiment with different subjects and scenes.

One quick tip: Make sure you get far back from the objects in your scene so that everything feels far away from your lens. That way, even if you're not shooting from above, your shot will have a clear sense of scale !

How to create the tilt-shift effect: the basics

Once you've selected an image, then the tilt-shift treatment can begin. I use Photoshop, and while I won't go into too much depth here, I'll give you a brief overview of the process.

First, you'll want to determine your point of interest. This is the most important part of the shot – it's where the viewer will look when they encounter the image. My recommendation is to ensure your point of interest is eye-catching from the get-go: a shiny building, a soaring church spire, etc.

Next, you'll want to duplicate your background layer (that way, you can always work on the copied layer – and if you mess up, or you want to start over, you can just make a new copy of the background layer and try再次）。

Make sure your duplicate layer is selected, then choose Filter>;Blur Gallery>;Tilt-Shift .

The Tilt-Shift dialog will appear, and you should click on the central circle and drag it to your point of interest to ensure the effect radiates from the right spot.

You can also adjust the blur intensity by dragging the Blur slider on the right-hand side, and you can drag the different tool guidelines to make the blur encroach on your point of interest more (or less) tightly.

When you like the effect, go ahead and click OK .

Next, I like to apply a Hue/Saturation adjustment ( Image>;Adjustments>;Hue/Saturation ), where I boost the Master Saturation slider to around +30.

Sometimes, I'll also boost the saturation of select colors – basically, the colors that I want to pop, such as the greens of the grass and trees, the reds of bright cars, etc. (In miniature models, colors tend to be very bold and saturated, hence this step.)

Finally, using the Curves tool ( Image>;Adjustments>;Curves ), I'll enhance the contrast of the image. Here, I generally just boost the right-hand side of the curve, thereby intensifying the light parts of the image while leaving the shadows relatively detailed.

And that's pretty much it! You can always play around with additional adjustments, but the above workflow should get you a convincing tilt-shift photo.

Go create some amazing tilt-shift photos!

If you've made it this far, I'm sure you'll agree with me that tilt-shift photography can be a ton of fun!

It's also a great way to turn relatively straightforward images into something much more compelling, without investing in expensive gear.

Like I said, not every image is a good candidate for tilt-shift photography, but it's definitely worth playing around to see what you can create! Don't just follow my advice; instead, experiment with all sorts of images. Maybe you'll hit upon a new kind of photo that works great with the tilt-shift effect.

Of course, we'd love to see the images you create – so be sure to share your favorite tilt-shift shots in the comments below!

Composition is one of the toughest topics for beginner photographers to grasp. Not only is it unintuitive, but it comes with all sorts of jargon, such as “dynamicism,” “negative space,” and “visual weight.”

In my experience, however, composition isn't as difficult as it initially seems. There is an array of handy guidelines to help you compose compelling photos – such as the rule of thirds , the rule of odds , and the rule of space – plus, once you understand a few core concepts, you'll start to move past these compositional “rules” and create well-structured images out of, well, nothing .

Today, I want to tackle one of these core concepts: visual weight, also known as visual mass. It sounds technical, but as I'll show you below, it's a surprisingly easy concept to understand. And if you put in the effort, you'll find that visual weight can dramatically improve your compositions.

So without further ado, let's take a look at what visual weight is all about, and how it can help you structure your photos effectively:

What is visual weight?

Visual weight (or visual mass) is the principle that some elements of a composition pull the eye more than others. Certain parts of each photo have more visual weight – that is, they draw the viewer's attention more strongly – whereas other parts have less visual weight because they attract less attention.

Take a look at the portrait below. Where do your eyes go? Mine go straight to the subject's eyes, because eyes have a lot of visual weight. In the example image, I'd say the eyes have more visual weight than anything else. They are the element exerting the greatest pull.

Notice that the subject's eyes are not positioned on the traditional intersection points created by the rule of thirds gridlines. That doesn't stop the eyes from drawing the viewer's attention, although it could be argued that the eyes' visual weight would be strengthened by placing them on a rule of thirds intersection point.

Which brings me to another key idea about visual weight:

The weight that an element has will change depending both on the scene and how it's photographed. Positioning the subject differently can impact its visual weight. Photographing in specific light, or shooting from a different angle, or moving closer will all impact the visual weight of the elements constituting the final image.

The essential principles of visual weight

Now I'd like to explore the key principles of visual weight (or visual mass) that you can use to improve the compositions of your photos.

1. Light tones are heavier than dark tones

Whether an area of your image is lighter or darker affects its visual weight.

Specifically, light tones and highlights pull the eye more than dark tones and highlights. As a result, bright parts of the frame are more eye-catching, while dark parts of the frame fade into the background.

Take a look at my example image from the previous section. Can you see the strong contrast between the model's skin and hair (lighter) and the background of the image (darker)?

It's easier to see in a black-and-white version of the same photo:

As you view the image, note how your eye moves toward the lighter portions of the shot and skims past the darker portions.

2. People are heavier than everything else

Curiosity about other people is part of the human condition. As a result, human figures have more visual weight than objects and non-human figures.

In other words, our eyes go straight to any human figure that is present in a photo. Faces exert a stronger pull than human bodies more generally, while the eyes (the window to the soul!) have the strongest visual weight of all.

The people in this next photo are small, yet our eyes are drawn straight to them:

This explains why you can use people, small in the frame, to give scale and context. It works because our eyes go straight to those figures as long as they stand out from the background (this is Gestalt theory in action !).

In my example photo, you can see how the inclusion of the human figures helps give the scene scale and emphasizes the size of the mountain behind them – without ever losing the emphasis on the people. The figures are small, but they are (visually) mighty!

3. Bigger elements are heavier than smaller elements

This principle of visual weight is pretty intuitive:

The larger the element in a photo, the heavier it is. Trees that stretch toward the sky are heavier than small twigs and bushes at their base. A figure that looms large in the foreground of the frame is heavier than a tiny human silhouette in the distance.

Note that this principle works alongside the others discussed in this section. A small human figure, for example, can have much more pull than a large, inanimate object – because the second principle of visual mass, that humans are heavier than everything else, comes into play. A small bright spot can also pull the eye very strongly, whereas a larger dark area will often feel relatively unimportant.

But for objects of similar types, textures, tones, and colors, the larger one has the stronger pull.

For example, the dials in this next photo are virtually identical in terms of shape and design. But the one on the right is larger than the one on the left, giving it more visual weight.

4. Sharp and recognizable elements are heavier than blurry and unrecognizable elements

Objects that are sharp (ie, in focus and crisp), as well as objects that are easy to recognize, are heavier than objects that aren't. According to Gestalt theory, the mind looks for patterns and shapes that help it make sense of chaotic scenes. Once something is identified, it gains significance in the frame compared to unidentified things.

The most obvious example of this principle in action is a portrait taken against a strongly blurred background. The visual weight of the background is reduced because it is no longer in focus and no longer recognizable, while the sharp face instantly draws the eye:

Again, this principle works alongside other principles of visual mass. A blurry face might draw the eye more than a sharp-but-unrecognizable texture, and a small-but-sharp object might draw the eye more than a huge, blurry object.

5. High-contrast objects are heavier than low-contrast objects

High-contrast subjects have more visual weight than low-contrast objects. This is a good principle to keep in mind when post-processing your photos, and it's also good to remember when composing in the field.

(When editing, instead of increasing contrast universally across the image, try increasing it more in the areas where you want the viewer's eye to travel. Lightroom's Clarity slider is an excellent tool for this.)

In this next example, I used the Clarity slider to emphasize the texture of the old car and help draw the eye to it:

6. Some colors are heavier than other colors

Color does affect visual weight, but this is where things get a little complex.

Bright, saturated colors draw the eye compared to dark and/or dull colors. But not all color hues are equal. Warm hues have more visual weight than cool ones, and red is the strongest color of all.

Simplifying the composition makes the relationship between the colors in the photo easier to see. If your subject is brightly colored, you can try positioning it against a background comprised of subdued, less powerful hues like gray, green, and brown. That way, it'll stand out more clearly!

The red figurine in the center of the photo below has a lot of visual weight. This is for a few reasons: It's recognizable, it's brighter than the surrounding elements, and it's sharper than the surrounding elements. (I emphasized the latter two features in post-processing by using the Clarity slider to increase its contrast and adding a vignette to darken the background.)

However, what really makes the red figurine stand out is its color!

How can you improve your compositions with visual weight?

We've explored the different ways an element can have visual weight and how you can expect the eye to be drawn around the frame – but what's the best way to put these principles into practice?

一些想法：

First, you can use visual weight to emphasize your main subject . Some of this is fairly intuitive; if you want the viewer to focus on a certain part of the image, you can make sure it's relatively large in the frame, that it's well-lit, and that it's in focus.

But you can also increase its visual weight by boosting its contrast and saturation selectively in post-processing. And you can adjust your perspective, camera settings, and focal length to position your main subject against a softer, darker, and less-saturated background.

Second, you can use the principles of visual weight to choose different subjects. If you want to capture an impactful photo, it often helps to keep things simple: one interesting main subject against a less interesting background. If you deliberately choose subjects with a lot of visual mass and you make sure the background has less visual mass, you can ensure that your subject stands out.

Third, as you become more experienced, you can play with different arrangements of visual weight. For instance, you can balance the scene by including equal amounts of visual weight on both sides of the frame – or you can deliberately create a sense of imbalance by keeping one side of the frame heavier than the other. You can include multiple elements with a lot of visual weight, and you can use them to draw the viewer's eye around the frame.

Finally, simplifying works for all aspects of visual weight. Eliminate everything that isn't necessary. Keep thebackground as simple as you can. Once you've done this, look at the remaining elements and think about how the eye will move around between them according to the principles of visual weight. The relationships between them will become clearer as the composition is simplified.

At the end of the day, by always keeping visual weight in mind, you can create more deliberate – and more sophisticated – compositions!

My absolute favorite photography subject is the night sky. As a more “conventional” professional photographer, I am often busy shooting pictures of people at weddings, photos of apartments, and images of models – but it's important to me that I regularly take photos for fun, and that's where my love for night sky and star photography comes into play.

Photographing the stars is, for me, highly rewarding, soul-filling, and oh-so-enjoyable! Capturing that sense of wonder that literally everyone feels (and has felt for millennia) while looking up at the night sky is deeply meaningful. I can certainly understand why you might want to do the same, so in this article, I'm going to share the methods I use to shoot the night sky. I'll discuss my recommended camera settings, my favorite equipment, how I like to edit my star photos, and more.

Ready to capture some epic star shots of your own?让我们开始吧！

What you need to take jaw-dropping star photos

Photographers often think that capturing amazing night-sky photos requires a ton of expensive gear. In my view, that's not the case.

Instead, to take great star pictures, you only need three things:

  1. A full-frame camera . This is because full-frame sensors offer better high-ISO capabilities, and night-sky photography involves shooting at high ISOs to achieve reasonably fast shutter speeds. However, if you have an APS-C camera that can shoot at ISO 1600 and especially ISO 3200 without a whole lot of noise, feel free to use it!
  2. A fisheye lens . This is so you can capture the widest possible view of the sky. Fisheye lenses do introduce optical distortion, but I personally feel this makes the resulting images even more jaw-dropping. If you prefer to shoot without this added distortion, or if you don't want to invest in a fisheye lens, an ultra-wide angle lens can also do the trick!
  3. A tripod . A sturdy tripod is non-negotiable for serious star photography; you'll be capturing long-exposure images that last 15-30 seconds, and if you can't keep your camera absolutely still, your photos will turn out very, very blurry.

The ideal camera settings for photographing the night sky

I've found that it's possible to get a good image of the stars almost every time with these settings: a 25-second shutter speed, an f/2.8 aperture, and an ISO of 1600.

If your lens's maximum aperture is f/4 – rather than f/2.8 – then you can try shooting at f/4 with an ISO of 1600 and a 30-second exposure.

If you look at my images throughout this article, you'll note that I've generally adhered pretty closely to these settings (though I've made minor modifications here and there based on the specific scene!).

The key is to keep the ISO at its lowest while preventing the shutter speed from going beyond 30 seconds or so. The wider your lens's maximum aperture , the easier it is to achieve a usable image with minimal noise and a sufficiently fast shutter speed.

(Why are these settings so important for star photography? That's what I discuss in the next section!)

Note: Capturing night-sky photos that show lots of stars doesn't really work when there's a full moon (or even a half moon). When you try to compete with large light sources – such as the moon, or streetlights, or electric lighting on the tops of buildings – the stars will be overpowered, and they won't be especially visible in the final image. That's why the best location for star photography is way out in nature, away from city lights that cause light pollution.

Why are these settings important?

The most fundamental component of my recommended star photography settings is the 25-second exposure. Since you'll be shooting in darkness, you need a long shutter speed to prevent underexposure. However, if you use a shutter speed that's longer than about 25 seconds, the stars will begin to blur, and you'll begin to see star trails. (Note that photographing star trails is a legitimate type of photography, but it's not the type of photography we're trying to achieve here!)

Since you are limited to a shutter speed of about 15-25 seconds, you can't use a narrow aperture and a low ISO. You need to let in plenty of light to compensate for the pitch-black conditions.

Therefore, you'll need to use your lens's widest aperture. Even with an f/2.8 maximum aperture, your photo might not be quite bright enough to look stunning, and that's where a high ISO comes into play.

You'll need to bump up that ISO, and I've found that on full-frame DSLRs, I can bump the ISO up to around 2000 without seeing much noise. On full-frame mirrorless cameras, you can go even higher; if you use a camera like the Canon EOS R5 or the Sony a7R V, for instance, you can get away with ISOs of 3200 and beyond without too much noise.

This is where you may want to consider capturing some test shots at different ISOs with your camera, then see what you think. Different cameras offer very different results, so it pays to understand the type of high-ISO images you can expect. (You don't have to try this while photographing the stars. However, the more realistic the scenario, the more easily you'll be able to understand how your files will look when you do a “serious” night-sky photoshoot.)

Plus, everyone disagrees about what level of noise is “acceptable,” so this will give you a chance to determine what looks good to you, rather than working purely off of my advice.

How to edit your star photos

I do extensive retouching in Lightroom after I take my night-sky images. I encourage you to do the same, though you don't have to use Lightroom; any RAW editor (eg, Capture One, ON1 Photo RAW, ACDSee Photo Studio, Skylum Luminar NEO) will offer similar capabilities.

I'll generally check whether I have plenty of detail in the sky, and possibly in the foreground, depending on the type of image I'm trying to create. If needed, I'll boost the exposure to bring out the details more fully. (If you nailed the exposure in-camera, this shouldn't be necessary!)

I'll then apply noise reduction to reduce unwanted noise (those pesky pixels that show up when you push the ISO too high).

I'll also make a variety of other adjustments. Here is a standard star photo of mine after editing:

And here are the Lightroom settings I used to edit the image:

Some notes on my edits:

You can see in the first panel that I bumped the whites up to +46 and brought the blacks down to -52. I wanted to emphasize the stars against the dark sky, and I've found a whites boost combined with a blacks reduction to be a very effective way to achieve that result. Pushing the clarity up to +55 also helped define the stars against the sky, making them nice and crispy. And I boosted the saturation to bring out the blue colors in the sky.

In the second panel, you can see that I sharpened the image a bit; this was to further emphasize the stars. At the same time, I boosted the Luminance slider to 33 to smooth out some of the noise, and I brought up the Color slider to 25 for the same reason.

A few more tips for great night-sky and star photography

Once you understand the star photography basics, you can have fun with more advanced techniques!

I encourage you to enjoy the editing process and play around with different tools. For instance, if you experiment with color wheel and color grading sliders, you can make the colors in your sky appear magical! In my example photo, you can see a little bit of turquoise in the lower part of the sky, and that comes from adding that color to the image shadows using Lightroom's Shadow color-grading option.

You can also affect the color of the sky by playing around with the white balance settings (ie, the Temperature and Hue sliders in Lightroom). This can create some pretty magnificent star photos. Take a look at this one photo that I edited three different ways, using only the white balance sliders in Lightroom:

Another pro tip – which I used in all of the photo examples that I shared – is to shoot your stars in context . In other words, don't just capture the night sky surrounded by the photographic frame. If you can include the silhouette or a pine tree or a house in the background, it really tells a great story. Also, including an object in the foreground to compare to the stars shows the magnitude of the scene.

Finally, make sure you know where the Milky Way actually is relative to your position. You can use an app like The Photographer's Ephemeris or PhotoPills to determine what stars are in the sky above you, where they're located, and where they'll be throughout the night (and at different times of the year!).

Go capture some amazing star shots!

I hope my tips and recommendations have been helpful to you! Like I said, I love capturing the night sky, and I really don't think you need tons of fancy gear to get good results. If you use the basic equipment that I mentioned above, and you follow my settings and editing process, you'll be well on your way to amazing photos.

Have fun shooting, and please share your pictures below!

The following case study on photographing a wrestling tournament was submitted by Ron Richardson.

几个月前，一位朋友邀请我担任当地中学摔跤比赛的摄影师。 I had never shot wrestling before, but I had spent some time photographing my sister-in-law's football games, so I had a general idea of how to photograph sports . I figured I might as well give it a try; hopefully, I'd get some print sales out of it from the parents.

Now that the wrestling tournament is over, I wanted to share what I learned, including several handy tips and tricks to help you get top-notch wrestling photos of your own. Whether you're a parent of a wrestler and you want to photograph your child's matches, or you're looking to shoot wrestling for a publication, or you just love the sport and want to capture local matches, this article should help you out!

让我们开始吧！

1. Work with a (reasonably) fast shutter speed

The wrestling matches took place in a high-school gymnasium, with 4 mats placed in a grid. The lights in the gym were bright, so I didn't feel like I was shooting in an ultra-difficult low-light environment. The problem, however, was that these wrestlers were not going to be standing still. If I wanted sharp shots, I knew I had to keep my shutter speed high enough to freeze the competitors as they grappled.

Now, the key to shooting sports of any kind is speed. You have to have a quick shutter speed to freeze the action. You do have the option to slow down that shutter speed, but you will have to pan with your subject . This can lead to some interesting shots (like the one below, which I took during one of my football photoshoots), but it isn't a reliable technique to count on.

So what is a good shutter speed for wrestling photography, and how do you achieve it? I like to have my shutter speed one step higher than the reciprocal of the focal length I'm shooting at. (This is similar to the Reciprocal Rule , though it's slightly stricter in order to ensure I can keep moving subjects fairly sharp.)

For example, if you're shooting at 200mm, the ideal shutter speed would be 1/250s. If you're shooting at 50mm, the ideal shutter speed would be 1/60s. But I've had success shooting at 1/50s, even at 200mm. It all depends on how steady you are with the camera, how slow the action is, and whether your camera and/or lens offers image stabilization technology.

In a moment, I'll discuss the shutter speed settings that I used during my photoshoots. For now, however, just bear in mind what I mentioned above as I share my next tip:

2. Widen your aperture and raise the ISO

I went into the shoot with my 55-200mm f/4-5.6 lens, but I knew that such a lens wasn't the best for wrestling photography. Instead, a lens such as the Canon 70-200mm f/2.8L would be a much better choice – the f/2.8 maximum aperture would have made it easier to achieve faster shutter speeds. I can't afford such a lens, so I shot with what I had.

I set my camera to Aperture Priority mode and dialed in an f/5.6 aperture . I chose that setting because a wider aperture results in more light hitting the sensor. Plus, a wider aperture provides a shallower depth of field , helping to blur the background (which was filled with the crowd and coaches).

Even with the f/5.6 aperture, however, I wasn't getting a shutter speed that followed the guidelines I mentioned in the previous tip. Therefore, I bumped up the ISO from 100 up to 1600.

(I personally don't like to use a high ISO – it produces unpleasant noise in the files – but I felt it was better to err on the side of some extra noise in the image rather than have card after card of blurry images. Plus, noise can be reduced fairly effectively in post-processing software, and today's AI-powered algorithms have been getting better and better.)

3. Use continuous focusing and Burst mode

Once I had my camera set at f/5.6 and an ISO of 1600, I set it on to my camera's AI-Servo focusing setting. (On some cameras, this is AF-C, or continuous focusing.)

Continuous focusing is an absolute necessity for any sports photography. By holding the shutter button down halfway and following the action, the lens will automatically update its focus to lock onto the subjects, even as they move.

Note that you'll also need to pay careful attention to your AF Area mode. This determines how your autofocus points are arranged around the frame. Different camera models have different AF Area modes, but if your camera has some sort of tracking mode – especially if it offers Eye AF, where the autofocus points lock onto the subject's eye – this is generally worth using.

If you can combine continuous autofocusing with an well-chosen AF Area mode, you'll find that you can often keep the wrestlers sharp as they move. Sure, you'll have plenty of out-of-focus images, but the goal isn't to be perfect; it's to end up with a nice selection of photos to tell the story of the match!

Also, setting your camera to a continuous shooting mode is very effective. You don't have to stress too much here, but if your camera can shoot 8+ frames per second, that'll definitely help nail some of those action moments.

4. Experiment and adjust as needed

I arrived to the tournament early, and I was glad I did; some teams were warming up, so I took that opportunity to take some practice shots myself. It gave me a sense of the settings I would need (see above!) and helped me figure out how the space was arranged.

The first matches began and I took about 50 images. Then, before too much time had gone by, I made sure to check the results. A lot of the images were blurry – the shutter speeds my camera was choosing ranged from 1/5s to 1/60s. (I was shooting on Aperture Priority, as mentioned above, so my camera was automatically selecting a shutter speed in response to my aperture and ISO settings.)

Basically, all the shutter speeds were too slow, which meant that my images were prone to both blur due to camera shake and blur due to the moving wrestlers.

Since the light in the gymnasium was relatively even all around, I decided to make a change: I switched from Aperture Priority to Manual mode, which let me dial in a shutter speed, an aperture, and an ISO independently. Specifically, I chose a shutter speed of 1/50s while keeping the aperture at f/5.6 and the ISO at 1600. Because the light was consistent both across the gymnasium and from match to match over the course of the tournament, I could comfortably shoot that way for the rest of the day without running into exposure issues. (And that's exactly what I did!)

Now, my chosen settings still weren't completely effective, as you can see below:

However, a 1/50s shutter speed was still quick enough to freeze most of the action:

Basically, I accepted that 1/50s wasn't enough to freeze the fastest action, but that it would get me a decent number of acceptable images. I could have raised my ISO higher in order to boost the shutter speed without overexposure, but I didn't want more noise in my images.

Note that many modern mirrorless cameras do offer outstanding sensors that can work at ISO 1600, 3200, and even 6400 with minimal noise, so this will really depend on your model! The more you get a chance to experiment, the better.

5. Zoom in on the action

The trickiest part about shooting sports is capturing close-ups of the athletes' faces. That's because the action moves fast, and when you're trying to shoot up close, it's very difficult to keep everything in the small field of view.

Additionally, close-up shots require either close positioning to the athlete, or an ultra-long lens. But I love close-ups, so I made a real effort to get some of those intense, in-your-face images.

Fortunately, I found that with wrestling, these shots are a little bit easier to accomplish. The mats are approximately 38 feet by 38 feet, and you can safely stand at the edge of the mat without worrying about messing up the competitors or getting hurt yourself.

Here, I was zoomed in at 200mm and was able to get a decent shot of both wrestlers:

6. Shoot with both eyes open

My final wrestling photography tip isn't as hard as it sounds!

Most of the time when we shoot, we have one eye closed and one eye looking through the viewfinder. If you keep both eyes open, you can still see through the viewfinder when you are zoomed in close – but with your other eye, you can see just how far away the athletes really are.

That way you can get out of the way if they are coming near the edge of the mat! (Note that you may not be able to get as close to the competitors as I could at this tournament, and you should always ask where you're allowed to position yourself before the matches begin.)

Shooting with both eyes open has another benefit: It can help you anticipate the action. With one eye, you can see the shot you have framed, but with the other eye, you can see if anything is about to move in or out of the shot!

My final thoughts

If I had a chance to do something different, I would have had a faster lens. That is a given. A lens with a wider aperture would have been much more effective – it would have prevented me from needing to shoot at 1/50s and ISO 1600. A lens with an f/5.6 maximum aperture is okay, but shooting at f/2.8 is much better (especially when making the athletes “pop” out from the background crowd).

Shooting sporting events can be fun, especially if you are near the action. If you are shooting a day-long tournament like I did, take lots and lots of memory cards (I had five cards, which ended up filled to capacity). Also take a snack and water. You will be moving all day.

还有一件事：

You might be wondering, given the slower shutter speed, why didn't I just use a flash to brighten things up?

But I don't like using flash, especially with sports. A lot of parents were at the wrestling tournament taking photos with flash, but as an athlete myself, I don't want to see lights flashing in my face all the time. Therefore, I would recommend against using a flash, especially if you are on the sidelines. I was typically only 15 feet away from the competitors, snapping shots off the entire time, so it felt inappropriate to use my flash.

Well, hopefully that helps – and the next time you're photographing wrestling matches, keep these tips in mind. I can't guarantee that your situation will be identical, but some of my experiences will doubtlessly be relevant!

Anyone with a camera can be a photographer these days, and many of those who do have cameras want to be professional photographers or artists. Over the past couple of decades, I've noticed a clear rise in people calling themselves “fine art photographers” – but who are these “fine art photographers?” What do they actually do? And what is fine art photography?

Maybe it's time to look into the essence of “fine art” so we can understand how it's different from “normal” photography, and what it is that fine art photographers do compared to everyday photographers.

What is fine art photography?

I consider this image to be one of my fine art photos:

On the other hand, I have lots of images that may be “art,” but they are not what I would call “fine art photographs.” This next image, for instance, isn't fine art:

I think both of my images would look nice framed and hanging on a wall. But if our goal is to identify which counts as “fine art,” only the first really fits into the category.

So what is fine art photography? Honestly, there isn't a definitive explanation or definition for what is a fine art photograph, but there are things that help us understand what it is and how to recognize it.

(Recently, I heard a photographer saying that you could add a wild edit to an image – like a weird curving blur – then you would be able to call it “fine art.” I don't agree; weird edits don't make an image “fine art,” they just make it silly.)

Anyway, when I was doing my fine arts degree, part of what was required was to take turns putting our work up on the wall for critique. During those sessions, we talked about techniques, about what was working, and about what wasn't. We would also discuss the ideas behind the work, and where we wanted to go with each project.

On top of those critique sessions, we had individual one-on-one sessions with lecturers to help us discuss our ideas and how to achieve them. The idea was to determine a plan for proceeding with our work, consider avenues for supporting the work, and to look at other artists who did similar work to see how they conveyed their ideas. These sessions were invaluable because they helped us work out what we were doing and the direction we needed to go.

Below, I offer a series of items that you generally need to think about before you can create fine art photos – and by thinking about those different items, you can start to understand what fine art photography is all about!

An artist's vision

Before work can become fine art, the artist has to have a vision of what they think their work will look like.

一个主意

Fine art is about an idea, a message, or an emotion. The artist has something they want to convey in their work.

That idea or message may be something small. It can be a single word, such as “abandon.” Or it might be a whole statement, like “exploring the way the moon affects the tides.”

It is a start. It is like a hypothesis.

Consistent technique

The work you create to demonstrate your vision and ideas has to have consistency to it. When all the work is together, it has to have similarities. Often, artists will use the same medium and techniques for each idea (ie, for each fine art project).

A body of work

In the end, you have to have a body of work that shows your ideas, subjects, and techniques. If you were to get your images into a gallery, there would need to be a uniformity to the entire collection.

An artist statement

Finally, you would most likely need an artist statement. This is a short explanation of what the work is about, why you created it, and how it was produced.

When you go to a gallery, you might look at photos and wonder what they are all about. That's when you should look for the artist statement. It will help you figure out the artist's intentions and the methods they used to create the work.

How to do fine art photography

You don't need to have a degree in fine arts to be a fine art photographer. However, you do need to think carefully about your work and what you want to achieve.

Here's an easy process for producing fine art images, and while you don't have to follow it, it can certainly help you out if you're struggling!

First, get your ideas together

Brainstorming is a great way to begin a fine art photo project. Simply sit down and write down your ideas!考虑：

  • What topics do you feel passionate about?
  • What messages do you want to convey?
  • What subjects do you like to photograph?
  • What techniques are you interested in?

Just write and don't take too much notice of what you are writing. This phase is about getting your thoughts down on paper. They might not make any sense at first, but as you work through your ideas, things will start to come together.

Once your brainstorming session is done, you should have the bare essentials of what you want your work to be about. You might decide to disregard a lot of what you wrote, but there should be enough to help you work out what you want to do and the direction you want to go.

Next, decide on your topic

Topics can be anything. They don't have to be heavy topics (eg, ideas that are really political or socially conscientious). My example throughout this article is “consumerism,” as I've had a couple of exhibitions based on that concept, and the idea that we're turning our homes into massive rubbish (garbage) bins.

Working out your message and the motivation behind it can be more difficult. For a topic like “consumerism,” you might want to explore it from a specific direction: the impact it has on the environment, what is going to happen to all the goods we keep buying, etc.

Find a subject for your photos

What is your subject matter going to be? If you're looking to create fine art photos addressing the topic of “consumerism,” would you photograph rubbish piles? Or would you look directly at the different brands and all the different products they come out with?

What your images include is just as important as the ideas behind them. Just remember that your subject should link to your topic or message.

Work out your technique

The technique you use for your photos isn't so important; it just has to be the same for all the images.

You can start by experimenting, but once you have want you want, then your body of work has to all be similar. You must create a cohesive portfolio that will look great and that work together when on display.

Create your body of work

You should now make as much of the work as you can. If you are planning an exhibition, then you need to know in advance – before you start making the images – how much work you will need for it.

When the work is complete, there are going to be pieces that simply won't work, and you will be better off leaving them out. It is difficult to determine what is best for an exhibition, but just because you made a fine art image doesn't mean it belongs as part of that particular project.

Last, write your artist statement

Once you've created your work, you're almost there – but you're not quite done. You need to write that artist statement! And it needs to be written in what is sometimes called “artspeak,” or language that fits with the art world.

In other words, it has to sound good. If you are applying to galleries, then they'll notice your artist statement just as much as your work.

Here is an example of an artist statement that I wrote about fine art work around the theme of abandonment:

“It is human nature to sculpt and contour the environment into shapes and forms that we find pleasing. We live in these buildings, work in them, and find entertainment and nourishment in them. We spend time in rooms designed to help us learn through many stages of our lives. When the buildings can no longer be maintained, they quickly fall into decay. My work looks at the rate of decay and how similar it is to the human condition. How easily we can fall into the same sort of decay when we are no longer being cared for. Through photographs of old and recently abandoned buildings, I want to explore the metaphor of the human condition with the deserted buildings.”

I just made that short statement up, but I hope it gives you an idea of what an artist statement is like (and what it should sound like). If you do a Google search, you can find many websites that can help you write one. You will also be able to find examples of artist statements so you can see what other artists are doing and how they are creating their work.

Go make some fine art photography!

At the end of the day, the work should be about you and what you are passionate about.

Don't worry about what other people think. If you know what your vision is, what your subject is, and how you want to create your work, then your artist statement should come easily, and you will find yourself on a new and exciting path.

If you are making lovely images without any of the above elements, then chances are you aren't creating fine art photographs. However, if you have a vision or message, and you have ideas that you want to convey through your work, then you are likely creating fine art.

If you want to create fine art images but you feel that your work doesn't meet the criteria I shared, perhaps you should think about what you want your work to be about. But remember: Your images are still art , even if they're not fine art , and it's also fine to take photos because you enjoy it, or because you want to create something beautiful.
